variable scope issues in Jinja2

Dec 14, 2014

I tried to calculate the sum of a sequence in a loop in jinja2 template but got some trouble. Below is my initial code:

 1 from jinja2 import Template
 2 text1 = """
 3 {%- set sum = 100 -%}
 4 <ul>
 5 {%- for i in range(2) -%}
 6 {%- set sum = sum + 1 %}
 7 <li>{{sum}}</li>
 8 {%- endfor %}
 9 </ul>
10 {{sum}}
11 """
12 template = Template(text1)
13 print template.render()

Here’s the output:

1 <ul>
2 <li>101</li>
3 <li>102</li>
4 </ul>
5 100

At the end of the loop, sum is 100, not the expected 103. I was confused at first. By doing some search, I found this may be the issue caused by variable scope. Then I tried to work around.

 1 from jinja2 import Template
 2 text2 = """
 3 {%- set l = [0] -%}
 4 <ul>
 5 {%- for i in range(2) -%}
 6 {%- if l[0] = l[0] + 1 %}
 7 {%- endif -%}
 8 <li>{{l[0]}}</li>
 9 {%- endfor %}
10 </ul>
11 {{l[0]}}
12 """
13 template = Template(text2)
14 print template.render()

Unfortunately assignment is a statement instead of an expresion in Python, unlike the assignment expression in C++. So we can’t use it in if and got the following error:

 1 Traceback (most recent call last):
 2   File "test.py", line 26, in <module>
 3     template = Template(text2)
 4   File "C:\Python27\lib\site-packages\jinja2\environment.py", line 906, in __new__
 5     return env.from_string(source, template_class=cls)
 6   File "C:\Python27\lib\site-packages\jinja2\environment.py", line 841, in from_string
 7     return cls.from_code(self, self.compile(source), globals, None)
 8   File "C:\Python27\lib\site-packages\jinja2\environment.py", line 554, in compile
 9     self.handle_exception(exc_info, source_hint=source)
10   File "C:\Python27\lib\site-packages\jinja2\environment.py", line 742, in handle_exception
11     reraise(exc_type, exc_value, tb)
12   File "<unknown>", line 5, in template
13 jinja2.exceptions.TemplateSyntaxError: expected token 'end of statement block', got '='

We need to find a function to set list’s element instead of the assignment expression. Fortunately we’ve lots of methods for that. 

 1 from jinja2 import Template
 2 text2 = """
 3 <ul>
 4 {%-set l = [100] %}
 5 {%- for i in range(2) %}
 6 {%- if l.insert(0, l[0] + i) -%}
 7 {% endif %}
 8 <li>{{l[0]}}</li>
 9 {%- endfor %}
10 </ul>
11 {{l[0]}}
12 """
13 template = Template(text2)
14 print template.render()

Now we got what we expected.

1 <ul>
2 <li>100</li>
3 <li>101</li>
4 </ul>
5 101

We can use dummy variable and set to replace if statement and save one line.

 1 from jinja2 import Template
 2 text2 = """
 3 <ul>
 4 {%-set l = [100] %}
 5 {%- for i in range(2) %}
 6 {%- set _ = l.insert(0, l[0] + i) %}
 7 <li>{{l[0]}}</li>
 8 {%- endfor %}
 9 </ul>
10 {{l[0]}}
11 """
12 template = Template(text2)
13 print template.render()

Reference:

Can a Jinja variable’s scope extend beyond in an inner block?
